chapter.htmlHeader: What else might it be?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Other serious sight-threatening conditions include:
    • Acute glaucoma — causes markedly increased intraocular pressure; it presents with pain in the eye, headache, and blurring of vision. For more information, see the CKS topic on Glaucoma.
    • Keratitis — presents with a unilateral, painful, photophobic, injected eye.
    • Scleritis — characterized by severe pain that is worse with eye movement. It is usually associated with headache.
    • Ocular trauma — for example penetrating eye injury, or embedded foreign body, or acid or alkali burns to the eye.
    • Ocular ischaemia syndrome — people have a history of poorly controlled diabetes, severe cardiovascular disease, and/or symptoms of transient ischaemic attack (TIA) or stroke. 
  • Non-sight-threatening causes include:
    • Dry eye syndrome — for more information, see the CKS topic on Dry eye syndrome. 
    • Episcleritis — this is painful but essentially self-limiting. Scleritis is much more serious.
    • Endophthalmitis.
    • Infective conjunctivitis — may present with:
      • Symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection.
      • The eyes are glued together by discharge after sleep, or mucopurulent discharge is seen on examination. For more information, see the CKS topic on Conjunctivitis - infective. 
    • Irritant conjunctivitis — conjunctivitis is associated with an identifiable mechanical or irritant cause, such as a displaced contact lens, a foreign body or eyelashes rubbing against the surface of the eye, or a chemical splashing into the eye.
    • Allergic conjunctivitis — conjunctivitis is associated with itching and recurs after exposure to a known allergen. For more information, see the CKS topic on Conjunctivitis - allergic. 
    • Superficial corneal injury — eye pain follows trauma or possible trauma, and a foreign body may be present. It is confirmed when an abrasion is seen after staining with fluorescein. For more information, see the CKS topic on Corneal superficial injury. 
    • Photokeratitis — occurs after the person has been exposed to ultraviolet light for example welding arcs, sun, or tanning lamps. There is usually a delay of 6–12 hours between exposure and onset of symptoms, but symptom onset can occur after 1 hour.
    • Subconjunctival haemorrhage — is asymptomatic and, other than redness, there are no other abnormal findings. The redness is well-demarcated, does not cover the cornea, and obliterates conjunctival blood vessels. For more information, see the CKS topic on Red eye. 
  • Rare neoplastic syndromes which mimic intraocular inflammation (masquerade syndromes), such as:
    • Lymphoma. 
    • Leukaemia.
    • Ocular melanoma.
    • Metastases.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the British Medical Journal (BMJ) Best Practice guide Uveitis [BMJ, 2018], the College of Optometrists guide Uveitis (anterior) [The College of Optometrists, 2019a] and expert opinion in narrative reviews Evaluation of the painful eye [Pflipsen, 2016], Chronic non-infectious uveitis in the elderly: epidemiology, pathophysiology and management [Gupta, 2006], and Investigation and management of uveitis [Guly, 2010], and a medical textbook Ophthalmology [Yanoff, 2013].
